Award.AwardTitle: Addressing Unsolved Questions on Weathering of Surfaces in Space by Fast Solar Particles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to advance the scientific understanding of the effect of bombardment of surfaces in space by fast charged particles (ions) from the Sun. Such effects include erosion as well as changes in both the chemical composition and the appearance. The studies will be done in the laboratory, in conditions similar to those existing in astronomical bodies without atmosphere. Examples of these bodies are the Moon and asteroids, which are the subject of planned human space missions. The results from the studies will advance science at the fundamental level but also will be applicable to new energy technologies; ion bombardment, for example, contaminates and limits the life of nuclear fusion reactors. The project results are also relevant to the studies of advanced materials; erosion by fast ions, for example, is of practical importance in the fabrication of high-temperature oxide superconductors and in thin dielectrics for use in microelectronics and photonics. The research will involve training of students and postdoctoral researchers in a unique set of experimental techniques.

The study will be the most accurate to date in reproducing the effects of the wind ions on the surface of the Moon, asteroids and other airless bodies in the inner solar system. The laboratory studies will use ultrahigh vacuum, in situ chemical analysis, and mass-selected ion beams. We will examine samples of lunar soils, meteorites and simple minerals using multiple surface analysis techniques and optical spectroscopy. The basic phenomena to be studied quantitatively include sputtering (the ejection of atoms and molecules by energetic ions), changes in elemental and chemical composition, and changes in optical reflectance. The project will examine chemical reactions induced by implanted ions, including radiation-enhanced aqueous alteration, quantify the volatiles produced, and measure the magnitudes of sputter erosion and re-deposition. For the first time, the studies will use simultaneous irradiation with both protons and helium ions, to unveil synergistic effects; irradiation of samples coated with thin ice will simulate interfacial chemical reactions that may occur in asteroids; in situ examination of elemental and chemical composition, including surfaces of carbonaceous chondrites in meteoritic samples. The study on radiation-enhanced aqueous alteration is expected to aid interpretation of asteroid Ceres, a target of the current Dawn mission of NASA. The project will also involve graduate student training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from NSF Award 1413380 allowed us to resolve several important unsolved questions concerning the regoliths of airless bodies in the inner solar system exposed to the low-temperature, cryogenic, and radiation environment of space. Our objective for this project was to combine laboratory planetary science with materials characterization to understand the fundamental physical mechanisms driving optical change in a planetary regolith due to material emplacement within the native space environment and/or concurrent with exposure to keV ion and soft X-ray irradiation. We did this utilizing special instruments that allow us to mimic the low-pressure, low-temperature, high-radiation environment of a planetary surface.

Deposits of optically-bright salts on the dark surface of Ceres have been observed by instruments on NASA's Dawn spacecraft, particularly in the regions within the central portion of Occator crater, implying geologically recent cryo-volcanism or extrusion. The bright salts were initially identified as magnesium sulfate hexahydrate; we found that Ceres' infrared emissivity spectra over the infrared range (5-17 um) match those of anhydrous sulfates reasonably well, and thus sulfates cannot be excluded from Ceres' mineralogy. However, laboratory measurement of the stability of hydrated sulfates showed the attenuation of spectral water absorption bands begins instantly under Ceres' cryogenic, low-pressure environment. An Avrami model found that magnesium sulfate hexahydrate grains dehydrate below detection levels over ~0.3 Ma at 200 K on Ceres, the average surface temperature.

Subsequent spectral analysis by the Dawn Mission team determined that the absorption features are more consistent with hydrous sodium carbonate within Ceres' bright regions. Our laboratory measurements eliminated natron (sodium carbonate decahydrate) as a constituent of Ceres' surface mineralogy in the equatorial region and the mid-latitudes without a source of continuous rehydration. The natron water absorption features were found to drop below Dawn?s Visible and Infrared Spectrometer (VIR)'s detection limit (< 2%) within < 6 days at temperatures ≥ 200 K. In Ceres' polar-regions (∼120 K), natron retains water longer, and may be observed over a few hundred years (∼300 years). We also found a temperature-dependent systematic shift of the 1.9-μm OH/H2O band center to lower wavelengths with vacuum-exposure at 200 and 240 K.

On the Moon?s surface, we found solar-wind-type helium irradiation of Apollo mare and highland soils preferentially removes O and Si, enriching the lunar grain rims in Al, Ti, Mg, and Ca. We can use these changes to approximate how long a grain has been exposed to solar radiation. In addition, radiation from the sun can eject charged particles from the lunar surface, forming a component of the Moon's exosphere that can be compositionally tied to the regolith composition via a set of conversion factors. We identified positively-charged Na, Mg Al, Si, Ca, Fe, and Ti secondary ions coming from the Apollo soil samples, and determined that the energy of these ions rises rapidly, are maximal at ∼5 eV for molecular ions and Na+, ∼7.5 eV for Fe+, and ∼10 eV for Mg+, Al+, Si+, Ca+ and Ti+, then slowly decrease with energy.

A model combining laboratory data with ion-solid interaction software (SDSRIMSP) was developed that can be used to estimate secondary-ion yields from small planetary bodies. Measurements of sputtered secondary ion ratios can be thus be used to characterize the planetary surface composition by ion mass spectroscopy in flyby and orbital missions. This technique provides a lower-cost option to sample-return missions to acquire information about planetary surfaces. For ambient solar wind conditions, we show that monitoring sputtered ion fluxes over the course of only a few days can provide global abundance estimates with a sensitivity of 1%. In addition, using published bulk compositions for a large suite of meteoritic classes, we have shown that secondary ion compositional ratios can indicate whether the surface is composed of primitive versus altered material for small solar system bodies such as Mars' Phobos and Deimos, as well as asteroids, Mercury, etc.

Micrometeorite bombardment of the lunar surface can be simulated in the laboratory using ultraviolet or near-infrared pulsed-laser irradiation. Using this technique on olivine, a mineral ubiquitous within our solar system, we find that laser processing causes the visible-near-infrared slope to redden and darken. Reddening in the olivine samples correlates with the production of "nanophase" metallic Fe (npFe0) grains, 20-50 nm in size, while darkening results from larger npFe0 particles, 100-400 nm diameter npFe0. Additionally, pulsed-laser irradiation reddens the Vis-NIR spectrum of quartz, and causes minor brightening. This is consistent with the formation of SiO or other sub-oxides absorbing in the visible, while the weak spectral brightening derives from a change in surface morphology of the sample.

A total of nine conference abstracts, six peer-reviewed papers, and one book chapter have been published over the course of this award, which supported a graduate student over 3.5-years, a post-doc for a year, and several undergraduate research projects.
